subject: Re: [junit] Support for JUnit
msgSnippet: It s a Yahoo Group: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/extremeprogramming. Join the group, then you can have daily digests sent to you by mail. There are usually
messageBody:
It's a Yahoo Group: http://groups.yahoo.com/group/extremeprogramming.

Join the group, then you can have daily digests sent to you by mail. There
are usually 300 messages per week.

Good luck,
J. B. Rainsberger <rainsber@...>

Hi Rainsberger,
I am a newbie here. Could you please tell me how can I be added into the
XP mailing lists. I have checked the www.xprogramming.org and could not
find one. Thanks!

qionghua


>From: rainsber@...
>Reply-To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>Subject: Re: [junit] Support for JUnit
>Date: Wed, 11 Jul 2001 11:24:44 -0400
>
>Too true. No amount of UI, documentation and fancy API can tell you "when"
>and "why" to test. For that, you need either experience or a coach. I
think
>this mailing list provides the necessary coaching. The XP mailing lists
>provide even more.
>
>J. B. Rainsberger <rainsber@...>

>Jim Cheesman <jchees@...> on 07/11/2001 10:59:10
>
>Please respond to junit@yahoogroups.com
>
>To: junit@yahoogroups.com
>cc:
>Subject: Re: [junit] Support for JUnit
>
>
>
>At 04:40 PM 11/07/01, you wrote:
> >I am not an agent of JUnit. What follows is my opinion and nothing more.
> >
> >JUnit is so simple that there is no need for support of any kind, beyond
> >this mailing list. I hope that JUnit always stays as simple as it is
now,
> >so that it never needs support.
> >
> >That's the beauty of JUnit: its simplicity.
>
>
>I'm inclined to agree... up to a point ;) Using JUnit is a matter of
>learning a new API - I don't think that support per se is really needed,
at
>most maybe some classes on how to set up the tests.
>
>Why up to a point? Because the api is only the "how" of testing - learning
>the "when" and "why" is another matter...
>
>
>
>
>
>--
>
> * Jim Cheesman *
